bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Bertha L. Lyons, February 23, 1948

div1.p: Hench informs Lyons that he has been made the custodian of an enormous amount of material pertaining to Reed and his colleagues. Hench makes suggestions as to what photographs might be used in the program for the Walter Reed Celebration. He also suggests including Cornwell's painting Conquerors of Yellow Fever in the project.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Bertha L. Lyons, February 23, 1948
div1.opener:
CC: Mrs. Blossom Reed
Gen. W. Reed
Gen. Kean
Dr. Sawyer
February 23, 1948
Miss Bertha L. Lyons
Assistant to the Director
Hall of Fame
New York University
1 Madison Avenue
New York 10, New York
My dear Miss Lyons:
div1.p:
I have your letter of February 5 asking for my help in the develop-
ment of a program to be used on the occasion of the unveiling of the bust and
tablet of Walter Reed in the Hall of Fame, May 20. I am so delighted that the
ceremoney has been arranged and I shall be glad to help in every way possible.

I have been made the custodian of an enormous amount of material per-
taining to Walter Reed and his colleagues. This material has been placed in
my possession by the widow and daughter of Walter Reed and by the close rela-
tives and friends of many of his associates, such as the Lazear family, the
family of Agramonte, General Jefferson R. Kean of Washington, D. C., General
Albert Truby of San Francisco, and others. As custodian of this material, it
is my desire to use it properly and in a dignified manner to honor the memory
of these distinguished scientists. Therefore, I am glad to make some sugges-
tions as to what photographs might go in your program for the Walter Reed
Celebration.

May I suggest some of the following: (1) The classical photograph of
Walter Reed. (2) An unpublished photograph of Reed on the way to Cuba to do
his yellow fever work. (3) Photograph of his birth-place. (4) Photograph
of the special Congressional medal given to him and to his colleagues. (5)
Reproduction of the famous New Years Eve letter which Reed wrote at midnight,
December 21, 1900 and January 1, 1901. This letter was written to his wife
in a spirit of humbleness and exaltation. It has been widely quoted in part.
(Certain personal parts of the letter could well be omitted but I believe we
could photograph the letter appropriately for the purposes of your program.)
(6) A photograph of the Schuler bust. (7) A reproduction of the Walter Reed
memorial stamp (with permission of the Postal Department). (8) A photograph
of Walter Reed Hospital in Washington, D. C., the greatest monument to Reed.
(9) A photograph of Camp Lazear in Cuba where Reed and his associates con-
cluded their epoch-making work. (10) Possibly a photograph of Reed's grave
in Arlington National Cemetry. (11) A boyhood photograph. (12) A repro-
duction of one of Reed's degrees, either his original medical degree from the
University of Virginia or his honorary degree from Harvard or Michigan. (13)
A photograph of one or two pages of his laboratory notebook in his own hand-
writing. (14) A reproduction of part of one of his letters to his wife written
during the excitement of the experiments. (15) Possibly a reproduction of a
part of one of his early letters to his finances before they were married, in
which he expressed even then, early in life, an earnest desire to help humanity.

Before definitely allowing you to reproduce the letters, I should
like to have the permission of his immediate family, his son General Reed and
his daughter, Blossom Reed.

One additional thought occurs to me. You will remember that the
frontice piece of General Truby's book comprises a colored reproduction of
the well-known painting by Cornwell, “Conquerors of Yellow Fever”. I had
something to do with the arrangement of this painting which was done under the
sponsorship of Mr. John Law of the Wyeth Company. On certain special occasions
such as for General Truby's book and for the reprint which I am sending you,
Mr. Law has permitted reproduction of this painting and indeed has, on oc-
casion, provided either the colored plates or the actual colored inserts at
little cost to the reproducer. May I suggest that you write to him if you
should wish to consider having a colored plate as part of your program. I
think it would be a very nice thing because as I must tell you frankly, there
are those whose loyalty is divided and who believe that Reed's colleagues who
helped him so much (especially lazear) deserve definite honorable mention in
any discussion of Reed's work. There may be some such in your audience and
the inclusion of this colored plate would, I believe, give the surviving rela-
tives of Reed's colleagues considerable satisfaction. I believe you would want
to reproduce somewhere in the program the citation honoring Reed made by Presi-
dent Elliott of Harvard.

Practically all of the items mentioned above I have in my possession.
Given a little more time, I could make other suggestions. It happens that
your letter caught me at a disadvantage, as I am leaving tomorrow for my first
post-war vacation. Mrs. Hench and I are going to the Villa Atlantique, Palm
Beach, Florida until March 1 and then we go to the Hotel Nacional, Cuba, should
you want to reach me.

I enclose an additional list of items. I would appreciate it greatly
if you would return this to me as it is the only copy I have left.

The man, above all, who was so close to Reed and knows so much about
him, is General Jefferson R. Kean, 2804 N Street, N. W., Georgetown, Washing-
ton, D. C. He undoubtedly will have some excellent suggestions.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
P. S.: I enclose a photograph of part of the New Year's Eve Letter and of some
stamps honoring the yellow fever personalities.
